summary: the first outbreak has subsided, but four subsequent seasonal epidemics were observed in china. the severe illness of H7N9 infections and the presence of natural reservoirs represent significant concerns. the identification of vulnerable subjects is paramount to the prevention of spread. age-dependent changes in the airway epithelium mean older patients may be more prone to respiratory tract infections [16] and the development of symptomatic H7N9 disease. comorbidities is the only independent risk factor for acute respiratory distress syndrome in H7N9-infected individuals. human respiratory tract primary epithelial cells were cultured from patients undergoing upper or lower airway surgery and experimentally infected with H7N9. the limited amount of primary epithelial cells available from each patient meant that only H7N9 virus infection was conducted. the viral RNA quantity was determined to represent changes in viral titer at each time point. dm virus or H7N9 virus-infected supernatants reached a plateau between 48 and 72 h p.i. differences in viral RNA quantities were not significant at each time point in the same NHBE cells. a Wilcoxon signed rank test to evaluate their difference between various time points. aP 0.05 was used to evaluate the difference between different time points. 82.87 11.28 93.1 3.79 8.16 0.55 0.061 90.07 10.2 88.83 31.91 44.41 4.84 0.099 72 h p.i. 108.42 16.02 119.69 8.8 19.46 4.1 0.051 74.7 3.2 74.36 4.72 13.15 2.09 0.066 IL-8 (pg/mL) 24 h p.i. 0.1 0 6.88 3.89 4.95 0.54 0.126 0.1 0 0.1 0 3.61 0.20 0.022 48 h p.i. 0.1 0 78.64 4.42 88.43 22.87 0.055 0.1 0 0.1 0 3.84 0.53 0.022 72 h p.i. 6.07 0.63 668.35 1.65 377.47 76.11 0.027 0.1 0 0.1 0 3.01 0.13 IL-1, IL-6, IL-8, IFN-, interferon gamma-induced protein 10 (IP-10) and TNF-. these molecules are also produced by human airway epithelial cells [30–34] and are termed “core cytokines” in the present study. Figure 1F demonstrates that levels of IP-10 in H7N9-infected NHBE cells were significantly higher than the others at 24, 48, and 72 h p.i. those of H7N9 and H1N1pdm virus-infected 24-year-old NHBE culture media were significantly higher than that of Mock at 72 h p.i. age 65 years, medical comorbidity, and obesity were not significantly associated with other patient characteristics. epithelial origin ( 95%) of cultured cells was confirmed by immunofluorescence staining using an anti-cytokeratin 19 antibody. inferior turbinate 35 Male None Yes 25 Bronchus 66 Female None Yes 26 Paranasal sinus 78 Female HT No 27 Inferior turbinate 40 Male HT, asthma Yes Abbreviations: DM, diabetes mellitus; HT, hypertension. viral RNA quantities increased significantly at both 24 and 48 h p.i. compared with baseline, followed by a plateau between 48 and 72 h after infection. variation in viral RNA quantity and cytokine levels in virus-infected culture supernatants between 24 and 72 h post-infection. all values were log-transformed (the only exception being percentage changes) and compared using the Wilcoxon signed rank test. the difference lost significance after adjustment for age, sex, medical comorbidities, and obesity. no significant sex-related differences in viral RNA quantities were evident. cytokine levels in virus-infected culture supernatants increased significantly from 24 to 72 h p.i. the correlations between viral RNA quantity and cytokine levels in virus-infected culture supernatants between 24 and 72 h p.i. were not significantly associated with viral RNA quantities using this primary culture model. characteristics, changes in viral RNA quantities, and changes in core cytokine levels in virus-infected culture supernatants between 24 and 72 h post-infection. a Indicates a statistically significant statistically significant. changes in core cytokine levels over time in relation to the anatomical sites of the explant and patient-related characteristics. levels of IL-8 and IFN- in virus-infected culture supernatants were significantly higher in the upper anatomical location group than in the lower anatomical location group, after adjustment for patient-related characteristics. 0.05, bP 0.01, and cP 0.001 were generalized estimating equations in which age, sex, medical comorbidity, obesity, and/or anatomical location were included as confounding variables. the viral RNA quantity was determined to represent changes in viral titer at each time point in the same NHBE cells. culture medium was the lowest from 24 to 72 h p.i. IL-6 levels in culture media were not related to virus type or donor's age. levels of IP-10 in H7N9-infected NHBE cells (either 24-year-old or 69-year-old) were significantly higher than those of the Mock and H1N1pdm infected cells at 48 h p.i. anatomical sites from which primary epithelial cell cultures were obtained were as follows: inferior turbinate (n = 14 [52%]), paranasal sinus (n = 4 [15%]), larynx (n = 1 [4%]), and bronchus (n = 8 [30%]. a lower anatomical location was significantly inversely associated with male sex. turbinate 32 Male None No 8 Inferior turbinate 38 Male DM Yes 9 Paranasal sinus 38 Male DM, HT, asthma Yes 10 Bronchus 47 Female None No 11 Paranasal sinus 56 Male None No 12 Inferior turbinate 49 Male None No 13 Bronchus 63 Female None No 14 Paranasal sinus 44 Male HT No 15 Inferior turbinate 24 Male None No 16 Bronchus 62 Female None all values were log-transformed and compared using generalized estimating equations in which age, sex, medical comorbidity, obesity, and/or anatomical location were included as confounding variables. age, sex, medical comorbidity, obesity, and/or anatomical location were included as confounding variables. 0.029a TNF- 1.46 0.07 0.06 139 38 0.003 0.036a Abbreviations: FDR, false discovery rate; IFN, interferon; IL, interleukin; IP-10, IFN-induced protein-10; TNF, tumor necrosis factor. all values were log-transformed and compared using the Wilcoxon signed rank test. kines in virus-infected culture supernatants increased significantly from 24 to 72 h p.i. the largest increase was observed for IP-10. IP-10 mediates both necrotic inflammation and lung injury [38] a Indicates a statistically significant FDR when the Benjamini and Hochberg approach for multiple testing correction was applied. associations between increased viral RNA quantities over time and core cytokine levels were then analyzed in relation to patient-related characteristics. 0.238 0.232 0.029 IFN- - 0.147 0.464 0.029 0.052 0.796 0.036 0.119 0.553 0.021 - 0.131 0.514 0.050 IP-10 0.255 0.255 0.199 0.014 - 0.052 0.796 0.043 0.044 0.829 0.043 - 0.465 0.014 0.014a TNF- 0.120 0.549 0.043 0.094 0.642 0.021 0.152 the presence of medical comorbidities was not significantly associated with cytokine levels at 24 and 72 h p.i., however, changes in the IL-8 level were significantly associated with medical comorbidities after adjustment for anatomical location and other patient-related characteristics. a donor's age might have an effect on viral RNA quantities (H7N9 and H1N1pdm) and cytokine levels (IL-1, IL-8, IFN-, IP-10, and TNF-) of the commercial NHBE culture supernatants. age 65 years could decrease viral RNA quantity and levels of IL-1 and IL-8, and increase the IL-6 level; male sex increased the levels of IL-1, IL-6, the levels of several core cytokines were found to increase significantly from 24 to 72 h p.i. in NHBE and primary epithelial cell models. high systemic levels of IFN- and IL-8 are associated with neutrophil activation [42] and can predict the need for inpatient care in H7N9-infected patients. adiposity has been shown to be a critical factor in the age-associated lethal cytokine storm in an animal model. adiposity has been shown to be a critical factor in the age-associated lethal cytokine storm in an animal model. we used a primary epithelial culture model to verify the viral response. however, we did not include control virus infections in the primary culture model. we confirmed that the H7N9 virus could replicate and induce a cytokine response differently from H1N1pdm virus in the NHBE experiment. all the procedures described in the study complied with the principles of the Declaration of Helsinki. written informed consent was obtained from all participants. patients were excluded if they experienced respiratory tract viral infections within the two weeks preceding surgery. primary cultures of human respiratory tract epithelial cells were collected from the following anatomical sites. samples were minced into cubes (2–3-mm3) and transferred onto a six-well Transwell cell culture system. each transwell was coated with collagen (30 g/mL), fibronectin (10 g/mL), and fetal bovine serum (10 g/mL) Triton X-100 (Sigma-Aldrich Co. LLC, Saint Louis, MO, USA) twice for 15 min at 4 °C. cells were then incubated with 2% bovine serum albumin. slides were then incubated at 37 °C for 1 h. experimental infections of human respiratory tract primary epithelial cells were performed in triplicate. cells (1 105 cells/well) were initially exposed to serum-free bronchial epithelial cell basal medium containing 0.25% trypsin. after infection, cells were washed five times with Hanks’ balanced salt solution to remove unbound viruses. qRT-PCR was repeated for samples with a Ct value > 38. quantification of cytokines in virus-infected culture supernatants. samples were initially incubated on antibody-coupled beads for 60 min to allow binding, followed by incubation with detection antibodies for 30 min. all data were analyzed using a bio-Rad bio-Plex Luminex 200 instrument. variable of interest Viral RNA quantities and cytokine levels in the H7N9-infected culture supernatants at 24 h and 72 h p.i. served as the main variables of interest. a value of 0.1 pg/mL was entered in the data set when an analyte was undetectable. at selected time-points, viral RNA quantities and cytokine levels were compared according to both the anatomical locations of the explant and patient-related characteristics of interest. the study was approved by the Institutional Review Board at the Chang Gung Medical Foundation, Taoyuan, Taiwan. all the procedures described in the study complied with the principles of the Declaration of Helsinki and the standards of good clinical practice. written informed consent was obtained from all participants. NHBE cells NHBE cells from two human donors were purchased from Lonza (Lonza Walkersville, Inc., Walkersville, MD, USA) cells at the third passage were grown into a confluent monolayer for subsequent infection experiments. immunofluorescence staining For fixation, 4% paraformaldehyde was applied to the cell slides at room temperature for 15 min, followed by three washes with phosphate-buffered saline (PBS) cells were permeabilized with PBS containing 0.3% Triton X-100 (Sigma-Aldrich Co. LLC, Saint Louis, MO, USA) twice for 15 min at 4 °C. experimental infections of human respiratory tract primary epithelial cells were performed in triplicate. cells were initially exposed to serum-free bronchial epithelial cell basal medium (Lonza Walkersville, Inc.) containing 0.25% trypsin. after infection, cells were washed five times with Hanks’ balanced salt solution to remove unbound viruses. nucleotide sequences were as follows: forward primer, 5′-GACCRATCCTGTCACCTCTGAC-3′; reverse primer, 5′-AGGGCATTYTGGACAAAKCGTCTA-3′; probe, 5′-FAM-TGCAGTCCTCGCTCACTGGGCACG-BHQ1-3′. negative controls consisted of sterile water and were subject to all the preparation steps in parallel with the extracted samples. natants The concentrations of six core cytokines in virus-infected culture supernatants were determined using the bio-Plex Pro human Cytokine 27-plex panel (Bio-Rad Laboratories) the following analytes were included for statistical analysis: IL-1, IL-6, IL-8, IFN-, IP-10, and TNF-. viral RNA quantities and cytokine levels were log-transformed (log10) to improve the normality of the distribution. a value of 0.1 pg/mL was entered in the data set when an analyte was undetectable. Spearman's rank correlation coefficients were used to analyze the associations between patient-related characteristics, viral RNA quantities, and cytokine levels. all statistical calculations were performed with the G*Power 3.1.9.2 software (Heinrich-Heine University, Dusseldorf, Germany), the IBM SPSS (version 23; International Business Machines Corp.) and the GraphPad Prism for Windows (version 7.0; GraphPad Software, Inc.) software packages.
